learningContent.title: Adding tables to a concept topic

lcInstruction.p: There are two types of table elements that you can add to a concept topic: <simpletable> and <table>. Simple tables are used to present information in a very basic tabular format. Tables are much more flexible in their ability to display information and allow for more complex tabular structures.

This lesson will cover the basics of adding a <simpletable> and a <table> to a concept topic. To highlight the differences between these types of tables, the same tabular data will be used for both examples.
Continue using the file 1_concept_images_tables.dita to add the <simpletable> and <table> elements.

step.cmd: Inside the <conbody> element after the <fig> element, add a <simpletable> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Duckling growth and development</title> <conbody> ... </fig> <simpletable> </simpletable> </conbody> </concept>

step.cmd: Inside the <simpletable> element, add the <sthead> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Duckling growth and development</title> <conbody> ... <simpletable> <sthead> </sthead> </simpletable> </conbody> </concept>

step.info: The <sthead> element sets up the header row of the <simpletable>.

step.info: You may add as many <strow> elements as you wish to a <simpletable>.

step.cmd: After the <simpletable> element, add a <table> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ...

step.cmd: Inside the <table> element, add a <title> element and populate it as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

step.info: The <title> element is optional, but it allows you to add context to your table, just as it does for images when used inside the <fig> element.

step.cmd: After the <title> element, add the <tgroup> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

step.info: The <tgroup> element contains the body of the table. The number of table columns is set inside the <tgroup> element using the cols attribute. In the example you added, cols="2" shows that this table will contain two columns.
A single <table> element can contain more than one <tgroup> element.

step.cmd: Inside the <tgroup> element, add two <colspec> elements and populate them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

step.info: The <colspec> element sets up your table columns and allows you to specify certain information about them using attributes. In the example you added, the colname attribute was used to name your columns "c1" and "c2" and the colnum attribute was used to designate the order in which these columns appear.

The optional colwidth attribute can be used to control the proportions of the column widths. In the example you added, the colwidth attribute is the same for each column, meaning that they will display at equal widths.

step.cmd: After the last <colspec> element, add the <thead> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

step.info: The <thead> element contains the elements associated with the table header. Unlike the <sthead> element in a <simpletable>, the <thead> element in a <table> may contain more than one header row.

step.info: The <row> element contains the elements associated with a table row.
